front.title: Deploying and Using Email in Deep Space

abstract.t: This document is an assessment on the email protocols to be used in deep space and provides recommendations to deploy and use email in deep space.

section.name: Introduction
section.t: Deep space communications involve long delays (e.g. Earth to Mars is 4-22 minutes) and intermittent communications, because of orbital dynamics. As discussed in , IP packets are stored by forwarders facing intermittent links, instead of dropping them. So packets may take a long time to arrive at destination, such as minutes, hours, days, weeks. The QUIC transport protocol, profiled for space delays, is used for reliable transport.

section.t: The source of this document is located at https://github.com/marcblanchet/draft-tiptop-email. Comments or changes are welcomed by filing a PR or an issue against that repository.
This subject should be discussed on the IETF tiptop working group mailing list.

section.name: Deploying Email in Deep Space Assessment
section.t: To send an email, the SMTP protocol is used over TCP. Prior to sending, the IP address of the recipient server is found by quering the MX records and then the IP address records (A, AAAA) of the MX returned values. SMTP goes through a series of messages between the client and the server to exchange capabilities, then sender and recipient email addresses and then content of the email, which results to multiple RTT to send the whole email.
To get its email, a user uses IMAP or POP, both over TCP.
A more recent email protocol is JMAP which uses REST over HTTP. This could be run over HTTP3/QUIC with QUIC properly profiled.
DNS insfrastructure need to be properly deployed and setup to avoid DNS requests through deep space links.

section.name: Deployment Recommendations
section.t: On Earth, current SMTP infrastructure is used. For email to be forwarded to space, an Earth gateway, as the last hop for email on Earth, should receive those emails by SMTP, looks up the MX and IP address records to find the IP address of the gateway on the celestial body surface network, converts the email to Batch SMTP MIME object , sends using REST/HTTP3/QUIC to the corresponding gateway on the celestial body surface network.

Reversly, an email sent from a celestial body surface network would be forwarded to the SMTP gateway on that network. The SMTP gateway then looks up the MX and IP address records to find the IP address of the gateway on Earth, converts the email to Batch SMTP MIME object , sends using REST/HTTP3/QUIC to the corresponding gateway on Earth.

section.name: DNS Considerations
section.t: For emails sending from Earth, the lookedup MX records and their corresponding IP address records should point to the gateway on the target celestial body network. Those records should be located or cached on the DNS infrastructure on Earth.
Similarly, it is assumed that on the celestial body network, there will be a local DNS infrastructure that has a cache of the related records, as discussed in .
Given that a celestial body network MTA can not lookup for all possible names, the names in email headers such as Received and others should not be looked up.

section.name: Unwanted Email Considerations
section.t: To minimize use of deep space bandwidth which is scarce, strong anti-spamming should be done before leaving Earth. As discussed in the previous section, an anti-spamming system on the celestial body network should not rely on any database or DNS lookup located on Earth.
